author: Jonathan Walker
title: Brexit would mean Hitachi won't invest in North East warns David Cameron
text:
Brexit would mean Hitachi won't invest in North East warns David Cameron 05:30, 9 Jun 2016 By Jonathan Walker The Prime Minister echoes warning from Hitachi chairman Hiroaki Nakanishi that a decision to leave the EU made the case for future investment 'very different' Shares Get daily news by email PA Wire Prime Minister David Cameron speaks during Prime Minister's Questions in the House of Commons 
Hitachi’s warning that quitting the European Union could force it to rethink plans to invest in the North East is “incredibly powerful”, David Cameron has insisted. 
The Prime Minister echoed the comments in the House of Commons after Hitachi chairman Hiroaki Nakanishi said that a decision to leave the EU on June 23 made the case for future investment “very different”. 
The huge multinational company is one of the region’s fastest-growing employers and will soon employ more than 700 people at its Newton Aycliffe manufacturing site , making new trains for the East Coast, Great Western and Scotrail lines. 
Mr Cameron, who is urging voters to support remaining in the EU, told the House of Commons that leaving would be bad for the economy of the North East. 
He said: “One of the reasons why international companies like Hitachi invest in Britain - of course we have excellent labour relations, the English language, a very hard working workforce, great engineers - but they also invest here because we are members of the single market. 
“And I thought what the head of Hitachi said this week about wanting us to be the European headquarters, to manufacture trains in the North East and sell them all over Europe, and how that might not be possible if we were to leave, was an incredibly powerful statement.” 
He added: “So in my clear view jobs come first, and if people want to vote for jobs they should vote for remain on June 23.” PA Wire Helen Goodman 
Mr Cameron was responding to a question from Bishop Auckland MP Helen Goodman, who claimed that economists who support leaving the UK were happy for manufacturing to disappear. 
She highlighted comments by Prof Patrick Minford, a former economics adviser to Margaret Thatcher and professor of economics at Cardiff University, who said in May that the economy would grow if the UK left - but the decline of unskilled manufacturing would be hastened. 
Prof Minford also said that the UK would continue to have advanced or high-tech manufacturing industries outside the EU. 
Mrs Goodman said: “With industrialists like Glaxo and Hitachi warning that if we left the EU jobs would be lost, the Brexit economist Patrick Minford has revealed that their strategy means manufacturing would be mostly eliminated. 
“Would the Prime Minister join me in calling on the Brexit leaders to says how many of other people’s jobs they would sacrifice?” 
Earlier this week, Mr Nakanishi said he was worried about the effect leaving the EU would have on the UK. 
Hiroaki Nakanishi, CEO of Hitachi 
Mr Nakanishi said: “I would like to explain how Brexit would affect us at Hitachi, and why we think it’s important for Britain to remain in Europe. 
He said: “For most global companies like Hitachi, the critical benefit of investing in the UK is that it is the best base for accessing the whole European market of 500m people. 
“There are other reasons like the size of the UK market, availability of local and international talent and the support of our local communities – which is why we take a positive view of the UK inside Europe. 
“Therefore we have our regional headquarters here and moved our global rail headquarters to London. 
“But take away the UK’s membership of the EU, and the future investment case looks very different.” 
Japanese firms invested in the UK and employed a British workforce because it meant they would be treated as European companies, he said. 
“We worry because those advocating Brexit have no answer to how the UK could negotiate cost-free access to this huge market from a position outside it. 
“It would take a long time and result in uncertain market conditions; during this renegotiation period, investors would probably be waiting to see the outcomes, hold back on investment, and jobs would be lost.”
